Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Undergraduate Research to be held October 19-24, 2014 in Tucson Arizona.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for student participation in the 30th Conference on Laser Science to be held October 19-24, 2014 in Tucson, Arizona. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities). This conference series is important to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

This Conference is part of the Division of Laser Science (DLS) of the American Physical Society (APS) and offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. A special undergraduate student symposium has been organized to allow students to present the results of their research and introduce them to cutting-edge topics in atomic, molecular, and optical physics. This Conference will be held jointly with the 98th Annual Meeting of the Optical Society of America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fourteenth annual DLS Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXX was held in Tucson, Ariz. on Monday, 20 October, 2014. The Symposium has grown from ten presentations in 2001 to fifty-one this year on projects done at about 40 universities or research institutes. This was the largest one ever, and is near the capacity limit for meetings in the present format. These Symposia have brought nearly 500 students to our annual meetings to present what are often the first research papers of their budding careers.  Programs, articles, further information, and photos from previous symposia at our annual meetings can be found at the DLS website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/ and the Stony Brook Laser Teaching Center website at http://laser.physics.sunysb.edu/research-symposium/.

The 2014 Symposium began with a buffet-style welcoming dinner on Sunday evening, 19 October, at the Doubletree Hilton hotel where most of the students were housed. There was plenty of good food, well prepared and nicely served. The evening included remarks by one of our hosts from the College of Optical Sciences at the University of Arizona, Prof. Poul Jessen. We were privileged to have the national director of the Society of Physics Students, Sean Bentley, and the editor-in-chief of Phys. Rev. Letters, Pierre Meystre, as our guests.  Afterwards students and faculty guests lingered in conversations with each other and with our high-ranking guests. 

Early Monday morning a pre-arranged bus transported the students 20 miles to the Starr Pass Marriott where the conference was being held (the Doubletree Hotel in town was chosen for accommodations because of the high cost of the Marriott).  The FiO/LS conference events began at 8:00 AM Monday morning with Plenary Session talks by several outstanding people, including prize winners Paul Corkum, the Frederick Ives/Jarus Quinn Prize awardee, and Moti Segev, the Schawlow Prize awardee. We also heard from Jeff Kimble, the 2013 Herbert Walther Prize awardee. Most of the students attended and were impressed and inspired by both the excellent talks and the seemingly vast audience of professional scientists.

Our Symposium events began at noon, most fortunately in the huge Tucson Ballroom E thanks to Alexia Marquez of the OSA meetings department.  It was indeed convenient to have the luncheon, the poster session, and the oral presentations all in a single, sufficiently-large room.  We had a sandwich lunch for our participants and honored guests, who included the three plenary speakers mentioned above; Richardson Medal awardee, Jannick Rolland; the 2013 the Frederick Ives/Jarus Quinn Prize awardee, Alain Aspect; DLS officers Toni Taylor, Steve Cundiff, and Anne Kelley; optics superstars Joe Eberly, Bob Byer and Arno Rauschenbuetel; and numerous mentors including Kristan Corwin, Jenny Magnes, Chad Hoyt, Grover Swartzlander (editor of JOSA-B), and others. The students were especially fortunate this year to have so many of the prize recipients and highly visible optical scientists meet and talk with them during the lunch and at the welcoming dinner. 

The Symposium events began with the poster session in the rear half of the large ballroom where many of the conference attendees stopped by to talk with the student presenters.  The session included 41 papers whose abstracts were published in an eight-page program (copy attached) and ran from about 12:30 to about 3:30. It was presided by Prof. Kristan Corwin from Kansas State University.
